This is a list of '''incorporated cities''' of [[Canada]] in alphabetical order categorized by province. More thorough lists of communities are available for each province.
{{Canada provinces map|Map=Political_map_of_Canada.png|AB =Cities of Albertaâ|BC =List of communities in British Columbia|SK =List of communities in Saskatchewan|MB =List of communities in Manitoba|ON =List of communities in Ontario|QC =List of communities in Quebec|NB =List of communities in New Brunswick|PE =List of communities in Prince Edward Island|NS =List of communities in Nova Scotia|NL =List of communities in Newfoundland and Labrador|YU =List of communities in Yukon|NT =List of communities in the Northwest Territories|NU =List of communities in Nunavut|width=400px}}

== Federal, provincial and territorial capitals == *'''[[Canada]]''': [[Ottawa]] *[[Alberta]]: [[Edmonton]] *[[British Columbia]]: [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]] *[[Manitoba]]: [[Winnipeg]] *[[New Brunswick]]: [[Fredericton]] *[[Newfoundland and Labrador]]: [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]] *[[Nova Scotia]]: [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]] *[[Ontario]]: [[Toronto]] *[[Prince Edward Island]]: [[Charlottetown]] *[[Quebec]]: [[Quebec City]] *[[Saskatchewan]]: [[Regina, Saskatchewan|Regina]] *[[Northwest Territories]]: [[Yellowknife]] *[[Nunavut]]: [[Iqaluit]] *[[Yukon]]: [[Whitehorse, Yukon|Whitehorse]] == Alberta == {{Main|List of cities in Alberta}} {{Cities in Alberta|Map=AB-cities-roads.png}} To qualify as a city in [[Alberta]], a sufficient population size (10,000 people or more) must be present and a majority of the buildings must be on parcels of land smaller than {{nts|1850}} square metres.{{Cite web | url=http://www.qp.alberta.ca/574.cfm?page=m26.cfm&leg_type=Acts&isbncln=9780779745739 | author=Alberta Queen's Printer | title=Municipal Government Act - Revised Statutes of Alberta 2000, Chapter M-26 (Section 82) | date=2010-01-01 | accessdate=2010-06-03 }} A community is not always [[Municipal corporation|incorporated]] as a city even if it meets these requirements. The [[List of communities in Alberta#Urban service areas|urban service areas]] of [[Fort McMurray, Alberta|Fort McMurray]] and [[Sherwood Park, Alberta|Sherwood Park]] are [[Hamlet (place)|hamlets]] recognized as equivalents of cities, but remain unincorporated. [[List of cities in Alberta#City status eligibility|Nine towns]] are also eligible for city status but remain incorporated as towns. {|class="wikitable sortable" style="width:60%;" ! width="*" |City ! width="*" |Area

Part of the St. John's Metropolitan Area |} == Northwest Territories == As in the other two Canadian territories, the only incorporated city in the [[Northwest Territories]] is its capital, [[Yellowknife]]. {{See also|List of communities in the Northwest Territories}} *[[Yellowknife]] - territorial capital {{Coord|62.45466|-114.3764|region:CA-NT_type:city_scale:50000|name=Yellowknife}} == Nova Scotia == [[Image:Nova Scotia base map.png|thumb|right|200px|Cities and towns in [[Nova Scotia]]]] Nova Scotia no longer has any incorporated cities, as they were amalgamated into [[Regional Municipality|Regional Municipalities]] in the 1990s. {{See also|List of communities in Nova Scotia}} *[[City of Halifax|Halifax]] - provincial capital and [[Metropolitan Area]], now part of the [[Halifax Regional Municipality]] {{Coord|44.64887|-63.57531|region:CA-NS_type:city_scale:50000|name=Halifax }} *[[Sydney, Nova Scotia|Sydney]] - former city, now part of the [[Cape Breton Regional Municipality, Nova Scotia|Cape Breton Regional Municipality]] {{Coord|46.13631|-60.19551|region:CA-NS_type:city_scale:50000|name=Sydney}} *[[Dartmouth, Nova Scotia|Dartmouth]] - formerly the second largest city in Nova Scotia, now a Metropolitan Area and part of the Halifax Regional Municipality. {{Coord|44.66389|-63.56818|region:CA-NS_type:city_scale:50000|name=Dartmouth}} == Nunavut == As in the other two Canadian territories, the only incorporated city in [[Nunavut]] is its capital, [[Iqaluit]]. {{See also|List of communities in Nunavut}} *[[Iqaluit]] - territorial capital {{Coord|63.71105|-68.32749|region:CA-NU_type:city_scale:50000|name=Iqaluit}} == Ontario == In [[Ontario]], city status is conferred by the provincial government, generally upon the request of the incorporated municipality. A municipality may apply for city status anytime after its population surpasses 10,000. This status is not ''automatically'' conferred on a community that reaches this population target, but must be requested by the municipality and granted by the provincial [[Ministry of Municipal Affairs and Housing (Ontario)|Ministry of Municipal Affairs and Housing]]. Not all municipalities which reach this population target have pursued city designation (as, for example, [[Markham, Ontario|Markham]], [[Ajax, Ontario|Ajax]] and [[Oakville, Ontario|Oakville]], which in 2006 had census populations of ''ca.'' 262,000, 93,000, and 166,000 respectively, but are still designated as towns.) Once designated a city, however, a municipality does not lose this status even if its population later falls back below 10,000 (as, for example, [[Dryden, Ontario|Dryden]].) City status may also be conferred on some rural [[county|counties]] which have been amalgamated such that all municipal governance takes place at the county level with no further municipal subdivisions. Thus, city status in Ontario does not always connote a primarily urbanized community. {{See also|List of communities in Ontario}} {|class="wikitable sortable" !City !! Census division !! Population

A ''ville'' might be informally referred to as a town or a city in [[English language|English]], but this is an arbitrary and subjective distinction. Quebec does, however, distinguish between ''villes'' and other types of incorporated municipalities, such as ''[[municipality|municipalitÃ©s]]'' and ''[[Indian reserve|villages autochthones]]''. Quebec did at one time distinguish between ''villes'' and ''citÃ©s'', but no longer does. [[Saskatchewan]], towns must have a population of 5,000 or more;{{cite web |url=http://www.qp.gov.sk.ca/documents/english/Statutes/Statutes/c11-1.pdf |author=Saskatchewan Queen's Printer |title=The Cities Act (Chapter C-11.1 of The Statutes of Saskatchewan, 2002) |accessdate=2010-06-04}} and meet other criteria in order to incorporate as a city, although in the early 20th century several centres such as [[Saskatoon]] and [[Regina, Saskatchewan|Regina]] were granted city status despite having a smaller population. The City of [[Melville, Saskatchewan|Melville]] retains its city status despite dropping below 5,000 people in the 1990s. [[Kindersley, Saskatchewan|Kindersley]], with a population that fluctuates around the 5,000 mark, has applied for city status in recent years. {{See also|List of communities in Saskatchewan}} {|class="wikitable sortable" |- valign=top style="font-weight:bold; background-color: #DDDDDD" |City | class=unsortable|Census division |Population

[[Dawson City, Yukon|Dawson]] was also previously incorporated as a city, but when the criteria were changed in the 1980s, its status was reduced to that of a town due to population.
